title: Move knowledge articles
content:
Use case

This integration enables you to import knowledge articles from a source Service Management tenant into the target tenant (local system).

The integration imports the majority of data from the knowledge articles, such as the title, article content, date fields, services, categories, and attachments.
However, it does not import audiences, models, related documents, task plans, and related asset models.

Set up the integration

As an example, the procedure below will set up the integration to implement the use case. This procedure consists of steps that you must perform on the target tenant (local system), the tenant where the documents will be imported. 

Prepare integration users

We recommend creating a dedicated integration user for each system.

Prepare an integration user in the source tenant: 

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user. 

  2. Log in to the agent interface of the source tenant as the tenant admin.

  3. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign the user an appropriate role to read knowledge articles. Alternatively, assign the tenant admin role.

Prepare an integration user in the target tenant:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user. 

  2. Log in to the agent interface of the target tenant as the tenant admin.

  3. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and assign the user an appropriate role to read, create, and update knowledge articles and the OPB Remote Agent role. Alternatively, assign the tenant admin role.

Download and install the OPB Agent (optional)

If the source system can directly connect to the target system, you don't need to use the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) agent. If there's a web application firewall deployed in front of the target system, the source system needs to use the OPB agent to connect to the target system. For instance, the source Service Management system is running on a public cloud and the target Service Management system is running in a firewalled on-premises environment.

To use the OPB Agent for the integration, perform the following steps.

If the OPB Agent is already installed and connected to your target Service Management system, skip step 1 and step 2 below.

  1. In the target Service Management system, download and install the OPB agent. Use the integration user created in the target tenant to install the OPB Agent.

  2. Import the CA certificates of the target Service Management system into the OPB agent's trusted keystore.

  3. Import the CA certificates of the source Service Management system into the OPB agent's trusted keystore.

  4. In the target Service Management system, add an agent. You need to specify this agent when creating an endpoint for the target system. 

  5. Launch the Endpoint Credentials Manager, and create a credentials record for the endpoint with the Rest Executor Domain 2.0 endpoint type. In the credentials record, enter the UPN and password of the integration user created in the source tenant.

For details, see How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows or How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Linux. 

Configure the target tenant (local system)

Perform the following steps in the target tenant (local system) as the tenant admin.

Create an endpoint

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the agent interface.

  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.

  3. Click Add.

  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint, and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint. 

  5. Click Configure, and then complete the fields depending on whether you're using the OPB agent for the integration.
    If you're not using the OPB agent, complete these fields.

    Field Value
    Agent

    Select Agentless.
    Authentication type Select SMAX.
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the source tenant: https://<FQDN>.
    Tenant ID Enter the tenant ID of the source tenant.
    Username Enter the UPN of the integration user for the source tenant.
    Password Enter the password of the integration user for the source tenant.
    Confirm password Re-enter the password.
    Certificate type Select X.509.
    Certificate format Select PEM.
    Server certificate

    (optional)
    If you're using the OPB agent, complete these fields.
    Field Value
    Agent

    Select the agent that you created for the integration. 
    Authentication type Select SMAX.
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the source tenant: https://<FQDN>.
    Tenant ID Enter the tenant ID of the source tenant.
    Credentials Select the credentials record that you created in the Endpoint Credential Manager.
  6. Click Save. The system displays a message indicating the endpoint configuration has been successfully saved. 

Create an integration

Create an integration and configure a scenario to define the business logic for importing knowledge articles from the source tenant to the target tenant (local system).

To create an integration:

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.

  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.

  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the target tenant and activate the integration.

  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.

  5. Select Service Management (under OpenText) as the connector, select the Service Management endpoint created for the source target, and then enter an alias for the mapping.

  6. Click Save.

Configure a scenario

To move knowledge articles, you can leverage the template: Move Knowledge Articles. The following describes how to configure a scenario based on the Move Knowledge Articles template. 

To configure a scenario:

  1. Click Add scenario.

  2. Enter a name for the scenario, for example, Move Knowledge Articles. 

  3. In the Template field, select Move Knowledge Articles (under OpenText Service Management) from the list.

  4. Click Save to add the scenario.

Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't use this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page.

Actions required before using the scenario

In the Settings rule at the start of the process logic, enter the details for the following parameters:

Parameter Action

SourceTenantId

 (Required) Replace the default endpoint name in the get_endpoint_info function with your own endpoint name.

DefaultService

(Required) Set the record ID of a Service Definition as the default value. This value is required in case the Service Definition of the knowledge article from the source system cannot be found in the local system.
DefaultCategory (Required) Set the record ID of a Category as the default value. This value is required in case the Category of the knowledge articles from the source system cannot be found in the local system.
SourceFilter (Optional) Add a filter to query knowledge articles from the source system. If the default value is kept, all articles are queried.
Size (Optional) Specify a value for how many records to fetch with each query.

Use the scenario

Once the endpoint, integration, and scenario are configured, click the Run Scenario button to trigger the integration. The integration will then connect to the source tenant to download the knowledge articles and import them into the local system.
